awd_titl_txt: Understanding the Use of Ecosystem Services Concepts in Environmental Policy
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will examine how and why the concept of ecosystem services (ES) has become an important component of environmental policy. Ecosystem services are broadly defined as the benefits humans obtain from ecosystems and the services they provide. This research will investigate what institutions and policymakers are using the concept of ecosystem services and how this use differs from previous ways of conceptualizing the environment in policy. It will also explain the potential successes and failures of this new approach in improving environmental management. Understanding the important role that social and technical factors play in shaping these concepts and use in policy is important as payments for ecosystem services have been promoted as a solution to a variety of environmental problems. This research explores how ecosystem services are used in diverse policy settings, and how the translation of ecosystem functions into monetary valuation has evolved in different contexts. The project will benefit society by highlighting what types of policies are more effective in engaging stakeholders in more appropriate ways. The project will also strengthen social science research on environmental policy-making while building improved global scientific understanding among undergraduate and graduate students.
 
Despite the growing attention to ecosystem services (ES) concepts, there remain major challenges regarding clarifying the values underlying the concept and translating it into policy. These challenges include identifying what counts as an ES, ranging from physical goods like timber to regulating services like soil erosion control to more intangible "cultural ES"; how ES can be valued in ways that incorporate diverse viewpoints and understandings of nature; and how payments or compensation for provisioning of ES can be designed and delivered in ways that are socially beneficial. This research project will aim to answer two key research questions: (1) How are ES defined, measured, and prioritized by different actors in policymaking? (2) How are different ES turned into economic values and through what means, and why are some ES paid for, while others are not? The research project will use mixed methods, including focus groups, participatory mapping, and interviews to assess local understanding, use, and valuation of ES in three watershed-based case studies, as well as interviews with national and international policymakers and scientists to understand the uptake of ES concepts, culminating in the construction of an ES database. While this project will assess these questions using case studies from Southeast Asia, the findings are highly applicable outside the region, and can illuminate ways to improve environmental policy-making and ecosystem benefit sharing in the US and beyond.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project addressed the growing scientific interest in ecosystem services (ES) and its application in environmental policy. ES are the benefits that people receive from nature, from clean water to carbon sequestration, and including these benefits in policy has been pointed to as a chance to achieve more effective and efficient management of environmental resources while garnering public support for access to these services. While ES concepts have gained traction globally, their effective integration into national and local policies has faced challenges, particularly in developing countries. This project aimed to understand the specific issues that have affected the adoption and effectiveness of policies for ES by using Vietnam, Myanmar, and Indonesia in Southeast Asia as primary case studies. The project’s research objectives were to understand the adoption and effectiveness of ES concepts in environmental policy; analyze how different ES are defined, measured, and managed in different country contexts; and examine stakeholder participation and the representation of diverse values in ES policy, including both monetary and nonmonetary values. To achieve these goals, the project used a cross-country comparative approach with diverse methods, involving interviews with 120 policymakers, scientists, and NGO representatives; household surveys with 500 households across the three countries; focus groups with local communities in key watersheds facing development pressures (223 participants across three countries); and development of a comprehensive ES policy database for Southeast Asia.

The research revealed several factors hindering the effective integration of ES into policy, including limited understanding, as decision-makers in sectors beyond the environment (e.g., finance, health or water) often lacked a comprehensive understanding of ES. Limited data availability led to oversimplified analysis of ES and neglect of cultural and supporting services, while difficulties in aligning ES management across different governance levels was often encountered. Unequal access to and benefits from ES, coupled with elite capture, undermined some policy outcomes, as pressures for development often outweighed the protection of ES-providing sites. Despite their high importance to local communities, cultural ES, such as recreational, spiritual, and mental health values, were largely overlooked in policy frameworks. ES-based policies also did not significantly enhance public participation in environmental policymaking, and monetary valuation of ES often excluded local input, hindering the representation of diverse values in decision-making. These findings highlight the complexities of integrating ES into policy, both in Southeast Asia and elsewhere. To improve policy outcomes, future governance approaches would do well to focus on enhancing opportunities for understanding of ES among decision-makers across all sectors; ensuring equitable benefit sharing of multiple types of ES; improving data availability on supporting and cultural ES; and strengthening stakeholder participation and creating expanded processes to include multiple values for nature in decision making. By addressing these challenges, ES concepts can be more effectively translated into policies that promote sustainable ecosystem management and equitable benefits for all stakeholders.

Key project outcomes include enhanced knowledge on ES governance, as the project generated policy-relevant knowledge on the conceptualization, operationalization, and financialization of ES in diverse governance settings, with an end-of-project workshop facilitating knowledge sharing with a range of decision-makers from the region. Training materials in local languages and an animated film were developed to educate stakeholders on ES concepts and challenges of valuation. A major publication, The Handbook of Cultural Ecosystem Services, was developed by the project; this comprehensive work highlights the importance of, and the challenges to, valuing cultural ES and incorporating them into policy. The project also fostered stronger international collaboration between scientists in the US and Southeast Asia through collaborative research, workshops, and course development. The project contributed to the education and training of 86 undergraduate and 50 graduate students in the US, strengthening their social science research and environmental policy analysis capacity.
